title: Powell hints Fed is leaving door open to another rate cut this month, citing global risks
text:
CLOSE Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says the U.S. economy is facing some risks at the moment, but overall it is in a "good place" and the Fed's main job is to "keep it there as long as possible." (Oct. 4) AP, AP

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell hinted Tuesday that the central bank is leaving the door open to another rate cut later this month, saying global growth has slowed and “uncertainties around trade, Brexit and other issues pose risk to the outlook.”

In prepared remarks he’s scheduled to deliver in Denver, Powell suggested Fed policymakers have not made a decision, noting the next Fed meeting is “several weeks away, and we will be carefully monitoring incoming information.” Policymakers, he added, will be “data dependent,” and assessing the outlook “on a meeting by meeting basis.”

But at the National Association for Business Economics annual meeting, he plans to add pointedly, “Taking all that into account, we will act as appropriate to support continued growth, a strong job market, and inflation moving back to our symmetric 2% objective.”

The Fed reduced its federal funds rate by a quarter percentage point to a range of 1.75% to 2% in mid-September, its second such cut since late July.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. (Photo: Wikimedia Commons)

While Powell indicated that officials are still weighing their options, he said nothing to push back at market expectations that the Fed will deliver a third rate cut at an October 29-30 meeting. Fed fund futures reckon there's a 77% chance the central bank will lower rates again at that gathering.

In the text of the speech, Powell says, “At present, the jobs and inflation pictures are favorable.” He added that unemployment is at a half-century low and wages are rising.” And while inflation is below the Fed 2% annual target, he said it “has been gradually firming.”

But he added, “There are risks to this favorable outlook, principally from global developments.” As a result of those factors, he said, Fed officials “have shifted our views about appropriate monetary policy toward a lower path for the federal funds rate and have lowered its target range by 50 basis points.”

President Trump's trade war with China has raised prices for American consumers, hurt exports and dampened business confidence and investment. U.S. and Chinese officials are set to resume trade talks later this week.

Any progress or stalemate In those negotiations could affect the Fed's decision. Officials also are expected to review reports on inflation, retail sales, business investment and housing scheduled to be released later this month

While the economy is still on solid footing, Fed officials have said they want to stave off a possible recession by next year.

Separately, Powell said the Fed will take steps to increase its nearly $4 trillion balance sheet by buying Treasury bonds to resolve a recent shortage of cash reserves in the banking system. That crunch pushed the fed funds rate slightly above the Fed’s target range in recent weeks.
